taskDescription:
You have a hand of 5 cards (that happen to create what’s called a royal flush in the game of poker): 10<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi mathvariant="normal">♠<!-- ♠ --></mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math>, J<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi mathvariant="normal">♠<!-- ♠ --></mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math>, Q<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi mathvariant="normal">♠<!-- ♠ --></mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math>, K<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi mathvariant="normal">♠<!-- ♠ --></mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math>, and A<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi mathvariant="normal">♠<!-- ♠ --></mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math>. Into how many different orders can you put those cards?
